Sports Direct owner Mike Ashley has made a bid for HMV that could see him add the struggling music retailer to his growing collection of troubled high-street businesses.

Mr Ashley was one of “several” parties that have put offers in for HMV, a person with direct knowledge of the situation said on Monday. KPMG, which was appointed HMV’s administrator after it collapsed last month, declined to comment, while Sports Direct could not be reached for comment.

Citi's daily wall of words looks like this.

BE11:27am

PM Theresa May will present today her
suggestions as to the way forward to deliver the UK’s withdrawal from the
European Union on schedule. There are currently no indications that she will put
forward a proposal meaningfully different from that which has been rejected by
Parliament last week, or that the EU would be willing to entertain fundamental
changes to the existing (unratified) agreement. At the same time, two
amendments will be put forward by cross-party groups of MPs, which are more
likely to alter the course of events in the near term, and also have implications for
the operation of government in the UK over a longer horizon. Those are: (1) a
proposal that if Parliament does not approve a withdrawal agreement by 26 February, Government is compelled to seek an extension of the Article 50
guidelines, i.e. that the UK does not leave the EU on 29 March as is currently the
default position; And (2) a proposal that a minority of 300 MPs from five different
parties can decide on the Parliamentary agenda, i.e. effectively opening the door
to legislation being passed by Parliament even if it has not been put forward or
agreed by Government. Both amendments are expected to be voted on 29
January, and we expect to be supported by a majority of MPs.

Pharma @wayneJ - the question is whether it is a real cost (i.e. one that will be realised mid- to long-term), or an arbitrage opportunity.Reasonable people should be able to disagree, but sadly this is Brexit, so not so much.
BE11:27am

Comment: the
first amendment (which we label the Cooper Amendment as one of its main
sponsors is Labour MP Yvette Cooper, but it is supported by MPs across political
parties) could meaningfully change the balance of probabilities between the
outcomes currently plausible: no-deal exit from the EU, the Prime Minister’s deal,
and an extension of UK participation in the EU in one form or another. This
amendment would de facto change the default legal outcome, currently a no-deal
exit on 29 March, to an extension of EU membership. This assessment relies on
the assumption that the 27 EU members would unanimously consent to
extension, since this unanimity is required, under EU law, for an extension to
take place. We believe that this unanimity will be forthcoming indeed. On the face
of it, this amendment should therefore lower the probability of a no-deal exit (to a
lower level, albeit not quite to zero) and it should raise the probability of a
postponement of exit. We believe however that this amendment may,
paradoxically, raise the most the probability of the Prime Minister’s withdrawal
agreement being passed. The reason is that if the choice were narrowed down to
this deal or no exit on 29 March, it is plausible that a substantial number of hardline
“leaver” MPs may shift their support to the Prime Minister’s deal, rather than
facilitate an extension. Either way, a reduction of the probability of no deal ought
to be positive for economic sentiment. We underline however that uncertainty still
remains very high, that the political process still extraordinarily erratic, and that
no outcome can be ruled out as yet, which ought to continue to act as a deterrent
to business investment in the UK. The second amendment (put forward by
Dominic Grieve) may have substantial implications beyond the near term. If
passed, it would constitute one additional precedent of rebalancing of power
away from Government and towards Parliament, by giving Parliament more
leeway to set its own legislative agenda, independent from or even against, the
Government’s wishes. This follows up on several similar steps over the past
months, which, in a political system where the Constitution is unwritten and relies
on jurisprudence, amount to a genuine constitutional reform. Beyond the
immediate impact, which would go in the same direction as the Cooper
amendment (reducing the likelihood of a no-deal exit), the Grieve amendment
may have longer term implications by making the task of government in the UK
more difficult in the future, as it may be more difficult for the government to
prevent legislative initiatives by backbench MPs that interfere with its own
agenda. This would be particularly meaningful in situations where (1) the number
of political parties represented in Parliament increases and (2) no party has a
sufficient majority of its own. Given the current trends in politics across the UK
(similar to the rest of Europe) both situations are increasingly plausible over time.
So while market-friendly in the near term (in the sense that it decreases the
likelihood of no-deal exit) the Grieve amendment may also be marginally
detrimental to the business environment in the UK over the long term.

We expect 2019 to be another difficult year for European Listed Property, and we reiterate our preference for subsectors with the lowest risk to rental growth and property valuations. We think the narrative this year will revolve around four key themes: #1. Yields look set to rise and act as a headwind. #2. Leverage will be in focus, but not just LTV, as ND/EBITDA becomes more relevant as rates rise. #3. There is no end in sight for retail property headwinds and we worry a perfect storm is brewing and #4. Brexit will dictate UK real estate share price performance at least through 1Q19 but even in the event of an orderly transition valuation follow through will be limited we think.

Curious Thoughts on Just Eat?
BE11:30am

Or in more detail .....

BE11:30am

Theme #1: Yields set to rise in 2019 and act as a headwind to the sector:
Real Estate is a defensive sector, outperforming on increasing concerns over
economic growth. JPMorgan’s house view is for economic growth to
continue, yields to rise and central banks to hike. We look to the US for
lessons, explore the impact of rising debt costs, and show how increasing
our average WACC by 0.5% contributes to an avg. 6% downgrade in PTs.
 Theme #2: Leverage will be a focus, but not just LTV as ND/EBITDA
becomes more relevant as rates rise. European REITs have benefited from
an extended period of low debt costs, which is forecast to have troughed.
UK majors have lower net debt to EBITDA than Continental large caps but
both are notably higher than US REITs.
 Theme #3: No end in sight to Retail Property difficulties, with a potential
perfect storm of retailer headwinds, disposals to come, more non-yielding
capex and high dividend payouts. We skew our valuation expectations more
negatively and find that it’s relatively rare for capital values to decline and
share prices to rise simultaneous…since 1987, in the UK this has happened
three times.
 Theme #4: Brexit will dictate UK real estate share price performance in
1Q-19, and although JPMorgan believes the probability of a ‘no deal’ Brexit
has decreased post the no confidence vote, we see underlying valuation
follow through for UK property as being limited.

Whilst 2018 has been a transformational year, 2019 will be
pivotal for the company. With a gap at the top in the first month
of the year, after today’s announcement that the CEO is stepping
down, we’d be concerned the competition may take advantage
of the strategic vacuum. The interim positon is to be taken by a
relative new comer – one has to wonder how the more veteran
senior execs are feeling. The reversal of the flat margin guidance
for the marketplace segment makes us wonder whether the much
needed investment they had been planning, to improve the
offering, has been reversed too. This is as good a time as any to
sink more investment into mitigating our eight point short case,
all of which are solvable, but at a price.

BE11:44am

With the previous CEO David Buttress in place for four
years (with an 11 year tenure at Just Eat as a whole), taking the company to its peak, and the new CEO Peter Plumb in place for 18 months, having spent eight years at Money Supermarket as CEO, potentially the mission Just Eat has before
it is bigger than we thought. Investment in delivery is the right thing to do (we
just think it has begun at least three years too late), but investment in technology is even more vital as players such as Deliveroo and Uber continue to shine (Uber Eats #1 app in 2018). Just Eat needs to take advantage of its data assets before its peers build up a similar level of competence, and it should think about other ways to assist the restaurants, other than just discounts (such as dark kitchens as per Deliveroo). It also needs to invest in ways to address its entire new incremental addressable market, which at the moment we believe is only 20% addressable (because you can only order food to your address, whereas you can pick up an Uber anywhere). Revenue growth is important for marketplace models, in order to scale and gain share, but it is vital to keep a handle over costs too. While its current remuneration policy is based on revenue growth, it has allowed its EBITDA margin for 2019 to slip below 20%, the first time since IPO nearly five years ago. Not what we want to see from an ostensibly high margin, high cash generative marketplace model.

The company also announced that FY18 orders are expected to be 221mn (GSe 221mn); revenues £780mn (GSe £779mn; company-compiled consensus £775mn) and adjusted EBITDA £172-174mn (GSe £169mn; cons £168mn). For 2019 they have announced guidance for revenues of £1bn to 1.1bn (GSe £1bn, cons £995mn) and EBITDA (excluding Brazil JV) of £185mn to £205mn (GSe £218mn; cons £204mn). Finally, losses through the associate line relating to Brazil and Mexico (now excluded from the definition of underlying EBITDA) are expected to be £80-100mn (GSe: £0mn).
There is a lot of information in this release. While below consensus, the EBITDA guidance of 2019 represents significant reinvestment, but is not as low as some investors expected based on our conversations. And we believe clarity here will be welcome to investors. However, management change, material Brazil investments and enduring key questions on long term strategy mean there is still a lot of uncertainty, which we believe will hold the stock back until we get more strategic visibility with the full year results in March.

We think Castorama has been underperforming the
French DIY sector for several reasons a) Customer perception of value
for money has suffered, b) It has had a weak digital offer, c) Its new
unified offer has not resonated with customers and d) It has been stuck
in the middle between more experiential and more convenient offers.
The work undertaken by RBC Elements, our data science team, suggests
a mixed picture demographically. Castorama has more stores in higher
population areas in France but Leroy Merlin has a higher % of stores in
faster growing population areas. Leroy Merlin has more exposure to lower
income regions, but also more stores and hence more traction in Paris. It
also appears to be stronger in softside and decorative categories.
